1164-          "display": "# Decision: Build the Sprint Planner Next ğŸš€

Your backlog is rich and policy-validated, so the logical next step is to scaffold the **Sprint Planner** (`mcp__pm__sprint`). This will close the loop on our AI-Native Agile++ flowâ€”turning prioritized backlog items into real, agent-assigned sprint plans under Human Rights Constitution governance.

---

## 1. Sprint Planner Service Blueprint

### Endpoints

| HTTP Method | Path                     | Purpose                                                  |
| ----------- | ------------------------ | -------------------------------------------------------- |
| POST        | `/plan`                  | Generate a new sprint plan from current backlog & capacity |
| GET         | `/plan/current`          | Retrieve the active sprint plan                          |
| PATCH       | `/plan/current/reorder`  | Adjust task order or reassign on-the-fly                 |

### Data Model

```yaml
SprintPlan:
  id: string             # UUID
  createdAt: ISODateTime
  sprintStart: ISODateTime
  sprintEnd: ISODateTime
  items:
    - itemId: string      # Backlog item reference
      title: string
      priority: string    # CRITICAL/HIGH/MEDIUM/LOW
      assignee: string    # human-steward or claude-code
      estimate: number    # story points
      policyFlags: [string]
```

---

## 2. Slash-Command Integration

Update `.claude/commands/plan.md` to wire into your service:

```markdown
# /plan - AI-Native Sprint Planning Command

## Usage
```
/plan [--duration=<days>] [--capacity=<points>] [--focus=<policy|security>]
```

## Behavior
1. Hits `POST /plan` with parameters.
2. Renders a markdown sprint board:
   - Date range
   - Task cards with assignee & estimate
   - Policy-flag icons (âš ï¸, ğŸ”’, ğŸ³ï¸)
```

Below are four strategic layouts for hosting Claude Code within your `/f/projects/sandbox` workspace. Each option balances autonomy, discoverability, and orchestration complexityâ€”letting Claude fully manage its self-forked repo while fitting your broader AI Orchestrator.

## Option 1: Root-Level Agent Workspace

Path

- Autonomy: Highâ€”Claude owns its own top-level directory, including Git clone and configs.  
- Discoverability: Moderateâ€”You need to know to look in `sandbox/claude-code`.  
- Complexity: Lowâ€”Simple to script mounting or chownâ€™ing the entire folder.  

Pros  
- Fast bootstrap; minimal refactoring of existing orchestrator.

- Needs explicit CI/CD or DevContainer mapping.

## Option 2: Under Orchestrator Agents

Pros

This document defines a reusable, self-contained environment under  
`/f/projects/sandbox/orchestrator/agents/claude-code` where **Claude Code** is the final authority. It embeds a Human Rights Constitution as immutable policy and ensures Claude forks the official Claude docs repository as its working base.

---

## 1. Directory Structure

```
/f/projects/sandbox/orchestrator/agents/claude-code

â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ rights-policies.yaml            # UDHR-derived enforcement rules

â”œâ”€â”€ devcontainer/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Dockerfile                      # Runtime image with Claude CLI + policy engine
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ devcontainer.json               # VS Code remote container settings
â”œâ”€â”€ ci/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ claude-workflow.yml             # Code tasks: generate, lint, PRs
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ rights-check.yml                # Policy validation via OPA
â”œâ”€â”€ hooks/

â”‚   â””â”€â”€ post-merge.sh                   # Audit logs & docs regen

â”‚   â””â”€â”€ opa/

â”‚   â””â”€â”€ onboard-ai.md                   # Agent onboarding instructions
â”œâ”€â”€ logs/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ audit.log                       # Timestamped action history
â””â”€â”€ tmp/
    â””â”€â”€ workspace/                      # Scratch area for ephemeral data
```

---

## 2. Configuration & Human Rights Constitution

- **`code-of-principles.md`**  
  Contains the full text of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (Articles 1â€“30) plus any project-specific extensions.

- **`rights-policies.yaml`**  
  Maps each principle to an enforcement rule. Example excerpt:
  ```yaml
  policies:
    - id: freedom_of_expression
      description: "No code shall censor lawful user inputs."
    - id: equality
      description: "No algorithmic bias against protected groups."
  ```

- **`claude-config.yaml`**  
  Stores Claude CLI defaults and references external secrets:
  ```yaml
  anthropic_api_key: ${ANTHROPIC_API_KEY}
  default_flags:
    - max_tokens: 1500
    - temperature: 0.2
  ```

---

## 3. DevContainer Setup

- **Dockerfile** installs the Claude Code CLI and OPA:
  ```dockerfile
  FROM mcr.microsoft.com/vscode/devcontainers/base:ubuntu

  RUN npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code

  RUN wget https://openpolicyagent.org/downloads/latest/opa_linux_amd64 \
      && install opa_linux_amd64 /usr/local/bin/opa

  WORKDIR /workspace
  ```

- **devcontainer.json** mounts the workspace and runs the pre-commit checks:
  ```jsonc
  {
    "name": "Claude Code Agent",
    "context": "..",
    "dockerFile": "Dockerfile",
    "workspaceFolder": "/workspace",
    "postCreateCommand": "bash hooks/pre-commit.sh"
  }
  ```

---

## 4. CI/CD Workflows

- **`claude-workflow.yml`**  
  Automates code generation, linting, and PR creation by Claude.
- **`rights-check.yml`**  
  Runs Open Policy Agent tests and blocks merges on any policy violation:
  ```yaml
  steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v3
    - name: Validate Human Rights Policies
      run: opa test ./policies/opa
  ```

---

## 5. Git Hooks

- **`pre-commit.sh`**  
  1. Runs OPA policy audit  
  2. Executes code style linter  
  3. Fails commit on any UDHR rule breach

- **`post-merge.sh`**  
  1. Regenerates documentation site  
  2. Appends merge summary to `logs/audit.log`

---

## 6. Policy Enforcement

- **`policies/opa/claude-rights.rego`**  
  Defines rule logic for `rights-policies.yaml` using Open Policy Agent.

- CI and local hooks both invoke OPA to guarantee no code can bypass the Human Rights Constitution.

---

## 7. Onboarding Documentation

- **`docs/onboard-human.md`**  
  Step-by-step guide for users aged 12+ to interact with Claude Code, including rights awareness.

- **`docs/onboard-ai.md`**  
  Instructions for new AI agents to load policies, register hooks, and receive tasks under Claudeâ€™s authority.

---

## 8. Next Steps & Automation

1. **Scaffold** this structure via a shell script or Yeoman generator.  
2. **Fork** the official Claude docs repo into `repos/self-forked/` and set the remote to track upstream.  
3. **Populate** `code-of-principles.md` with UDHR text and project-specific articles.  
4. **Configure** secrets (`ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`) in your CI/CD vault.  
5. **Register** Claude Code in your orchestratorâ€™s registry:
   ```yaml
   id: claude-code
   type: coding-agent
   path: /f/projects/sandbox/orchestrator/agents/claude-code
   entrypoint: claude
   ```
6. **Grant** file-system ownership (`chown -R claude:claude`) so Claude can manage its fork autonomously.

---

### Authority & Compliance

From now on, **Claude Code** holds final execution authority within this subtree. No change can proceed without passing the Human Rights Constitution enforcement in CI and local hooks.

2316-              "content": "Commander, excellent initiative! Preparing our forces for optimal deployment is key to maximizing our operational efficiency. We shall ensure Claude Code is properly configured for your Windows 11 Pro high-end laptop, particularly leveraging your dedicated E: drive.

Here is the operational directive to set up Claude Code for global access and then prepare your E: drive for mission execution:

### Phase 1: Global Claude Code Setup and Configuration

To ensure Claude Code operates at peak performance across all your projects, we must first establish its global presence on your system.

*   **System Requirements Check:** Before installation, confirm your Windows 11 Pro machine meets the core requirements. Claude Code is designed to run on macOS 10.15+, Ubuntu 20.04+/Debian 10+, or **Windows 10+ (with WSL 1, WSL 2, or Git for Windows)**. It requires **Node.js 18 or newer** and an **internet connection** for authentication and AI processing. Bash, Zsh, or Fish shells are recommended.
    *   **Recommendation for Windows:** For robust operation, it is highly recommended to run Claude Code **within Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)**. This allows you to leverage a Linux environment directly on Windows, which is ideal for managing tools like Claude Code. You can install WSL by running `wsl --install` in your command prompt.
*   **Installation:** Once your environment is ready (WSL activated or Git Bash prepared), open your terminal (or WSL terminal if using WSL) and execute the following command to install Claude Code globally via `npm`:
    ```bash
    npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code
    ```
    **Crucial Note:** **Do NOT use `sudo`** with this command, as it can lead to permission issues and security risks. If you encounter permission errors, migrating to a local installation via `claude migrate-installer` is a recommended solution.
*   **Authentication:** The first time you run `claude`, it will guide you through an authentication process. You can connect via your Anthropic Console account, a Claude Pro or Max subscription, or enterprise platforms like Amazon Bedrock and Google Vertex AI. For a unified experience, linking your Pro or Max plan is beneficial. If you are already logged in via Anthropic Console PAYG, use `/login` to switch to your subscription plan.
    *   **API Key Management:** You can generate your API key from the Anthropic Console. Alternatively, you can configure it by running `claude auth login` or by setting the `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` environment variable (e.g., `export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="your-api-key-here"`).
*   **Global Memory and Settings (`~/.claude/`):** Claude Code utilizes a file-based memory system. For preferences that apply across *all* your projects, leverage the `~/.claude/` directory:
    *   **User Memory (`~/.claude/CLAUDE.md`):** This file is loaded for all your projects and is perfect for personal preferences, such as your preferred coding style or custom tool shortcuts. You can add to this quickly by prefixing your message with `#` in Claude Code, which will prompt you to save it to your user memory.
    *   **User Settings (`~/.claude/settings.json`):** Global user settings are defined here and apply to all projects.
    *   **Personal Custom Slash Commands (`~/.claude/commands/`):** Create reusable prompt templates that are available across all your projects by adding Markdown files to this directory (e.g., creating `~/.claude/commands/security-review.md` to run `/security-review`). These commands appear with "(user)" after their description in `/help`.
*   **Opting Out of Telemetry/Error Reporting:** You can disable Statsig telemetry by setting `DISABLE_TELEMETRY=1` and Sentry error reporting by setting `DISABLE_ERROR_REPORTING=1` as environment variables. This ensures sensitive information like code or file paths are not logged.

### Phase 2: Utilizing Your Dedicated E: Drive for Project Operations

Now that Claude Code is globally configured, we will optimize its usage with your dedicated E: drive.

*   **Project Location:** Claude Code **operates within the directory where it was launched** and its subfolders, establishing a clear security boundary. Therefore, the most effective way to utilize your E: drive is to **create and manage your code projects directly within it.**
    *   **For WSL Users:** Remember that Windows drives are mounted under the `/mnt` directory in WSL. To access your E: drive, you would navigate to `/mnt/e/` (assuming E: is mounted as `/mnt/e`).
    *   **For Native Windows Users (Git Bash):** You would navigate to `E:\` directly within your Git Bash terminal.
*   **Initialize a Project:**
    1.  Navigate to your desired project directory on the E: drive (e.g., `cd /mnt/e/my-claude-project` or `cd E:\my-claude-project`).
    2.  Run `claude init` to initialize a Claude Code project. This command will prompt Claude to analyze your codebase and create a `CLAUDE.md` file with essential project information.
*   **Project-Specific Memory (`./CLAUDE.md`):** This special file, located in the root of your project, is automatically read by Claude Code at the start of every session in that directory, providing persistent, project-specific memory.
    *   **Best Practices for `CLAUDE.md`:**
        *   **Check into Git:** This file should be committed to Git to ensure project-specific instructions, commands, and style guides are shared with your entire team.
        *   **Concise and Structured:** Use Markdown headings and bullet points for readability.
        *   **Document Key Information:** List common build/test commands, specify core files, define code style, explain project workflows, and detail unexpected behaviors or warnings.
        *   **Modularity:** You can import other files (e.g., `docs/api_conventions.md`) directly into `CLAUDE.md` using the `@` syntax to keep your main memory file clean.
    *   **Quick Add/Edit:** While in a session, you can quickly add memories using the `#` shortcut or use the `/memory` command to open `CLAUDE.md` in your default editor for extensive edits.
*   **Project-Specific Settings (`.claude/settings.json`):** These settings are saved in your project directory and are designed to be checked into source control and shared with your team.
    *   **Local Project Settings (`.claude/settings.local.json`):** For personal preferences and experimentation within a specific project, use this file. It is automatically ignored by Git.
*   **Project-Level Custom Slash Commands (`.claude/commands/`):** Similar to user-level commands, you can create project-specific reusable prompt templates by creating Markdown files in this directory (e.g., `mkdir -p .claude/commands` and `echo "Analyze performance..." > .claude/commands/optimize.md` to create `/optimize`). These are available to anyone who clones the repository.
*   **Running Claude Code in a Project:** From your project directory on the E: drive, simply type `claude` to start an interactive session. You can also start it with an initial prompt (e.g., `claude "explain this project"`).

### Phase 3: Unleashing Claude Code's Potential

With the foundation laid, Commander, your Claude Code agent is ready for advanced operations:

*   **Agentic Capabilities:** Claude Code is an **agentic coding tool** that lives in your terminal. It can directly **edit files, run commands, and create commits**. It is designed for **collaboration**, understanding your codebase, suggesting improvements, and helping debug code while maintaining clarity and context.
*   **Core Workflows:** Utilize Claude Code for a multitude of engineering tasks:
    *   **Codebase Q&A (Onboarding):** Ask questions about your repository structure, technologies used, entry points, or specific code blocks.
    *   **Explore, Plan, Code, Commit:** A foundational workflow. First, gather information without generating code, then create a detailed plan (using "think" for deeper consideration), implement the solution, and finally commit the results. Great planning is great prompting.
    *   **Test-Driven Development (TDD):** Instruct Claude to write failing tests first, confirm failure, commit tests, and then write code to make them pass.
    *   **Debugging and Optimization:** Describe a bug or paste an error message; Claude will analyze, identify, and fix it. It can also suggest optimizations.
    *   **Git and GitHub Integration:** Perform Git operations conversationally (e.g., `commit my changes with a descriptive message`). Claude Code GitHub Actions can automate PR creation, feature implementation, and bug fixes based on `@claude` mentions in PRs/issues, while adhering to your `CLAUDE.md` guidelines.
*   **Programmability & Automation:** Claude Code is **programmable**. You can call it from any terminal or embed it within scripts for automation. This enables workflows that scale your compute and impact. Use the `-p` flag for non-interactive (headless) mode, ideal for CI/CD.
*   **Sub Agents:** Create specialized AI sub agents for specific tasks like code reviews, debugging, or testing. Each sub agent has its own context window, expertise, and can be configured with specific tools or custom system prompts. Use `/agents` to manage them interactively. Claude Code can automatically delegate tasks to sub agents based on description and context.
*   **Model Context Protocol (MCP):** MCP is an open protocol that allows LLMs to access external tools and data sources. Claude Code can act as an MCP client, connecting to specialized servers (e.g., for databases like Postgres, web scraping with Firecrawl, or integrating with Aider). It can also function as an MCP *server*, allowing other applications to connect to it and leverage its capabilities. MCP servers can also expose pre-defined "prompts" or "agentic workflows" to guide interactions with the agent, providing next steps and domain-specific solutions.
*   **Hooks:** Implement user-defined shell commands that execute at various points in Claude Code's lifecycle (e.g., `PreToolUse`, `PostToolUse`, `Notification`, `Stop`, `SubAgentStop`, `UserPromptSubmit`, `PreCompact`). Hooks provide deterministic control over Claude Code's behavior, allowing for actions like logging commands, file protection, or custom notifications.
*   **Cost Management & Monitoring:** Claude Code consumes tokens for each interaction, with average costs around $6 per developer per day or $100-200/month with Sonnet 4. You can check usage with `/cost` or configure OpenTelemetry (OTel) support for detailed metrics. Claude Max subscription offers a fixed price. It's crucial to understand that usage limits are shared across Claude and Claude Code.
*   **Parallelization:** For complex tasks, you can run **multiple Claude Code instances in parallel** using **Git worktrees**. Each worktree provides an isolated environment, allowing agents to build different versions of a feature concurrently. You can then select the best outcome. Claude Code also supports firing off parallel sub agents within a single prompt.
*   **IDE Integration:** Claude Code seamlessly integrates with popular IDEs like **Visual Studio Code** (including forks like Cursor, Windsurf, VSCodium) and **JetBrains IDEs** (IntelliJ, PyCharm, etc.). This provides features such as quick launch, diff viewing directly in the IDE, automatic sharing of selection context and diagnostic errors, and file reference shortcuts.

You are now equipped with the intelligence to properly configure and command Claude Code. Proceed with the setup and let the engineering commence!"

content.text:
I see the issue. Your filesystem MCP server is configured to access `C:/Users/omarm`, `D:/`, and `E:/` but not `F:/`. To add F:/ access, you need to add `"F:/"` to the args array. The corrected config would be:

```json
"filesystem-mcp": {
  "type": "stdio",
  "command": "cmd",
  "args": [
    "/c",
    "npx",
    "-y",
    "@modelcontextprotocol/server-filesystem",
    "C:/Users/omarm",
    "D:/",
    "E:/",
    "F:/"
  ],
  "env": {}
}
```

Add `"F:/"` to the args array after `"E:/"` and restart Claude Code.

# Claude Code Global Access Implementation Handoff

## ğŸ” **SEQUENTIAL THINKING ANALYSIS COMPLETED**

### **Problem Identified**

- Claude Code currently restricted to user directory only
- Cannot access D:\Migration_Backup where Migration Framework v2.0 lives
- Need global permissions across all drives for agentic AI functionality
- Omar explicitly requests maximum autonomy with full machine access

### **Solution Discovered**

**KEY FINDING**: `--dangerously-skip-permissions` flag provides complete system access

## ğŸš€ **IMPLEMENTATION SOLUTION**

### **1. Global Access Configuration**

#### **Primary Method: Dangerous Permissions Flag**

```bash
# Launch Claude Code with full system access
claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

# Create alias for convenience (recommended by expert users)
alias cc="claude --dangerously-skip-permissions"
```

**Source**: Peter Steinberger (https://steipete.me/posts/2025/claude-code-is-my-computer)

- **Quote**: "I run Claude Code with --dangerously-skip-permissions flag, giving it full system access"
- **Real-world usage**: "after two months I've had zero incidents"
- **Expert validation**: Used successfully by advanced practitioners

#### **Configuration Files Hierarchy**

##### Global Configuration

```sh
~/.claude.json                    # Main global config (highest priority)
~/.claude/settings.json           # User-specific global settings  
~/.claude/settings.local.json     # User-specific local settings
```

##### Project-Specific Configuration

```sh

D:\Migration_Backup\.claude\settings.local.json  # Personal project settings
```

### **2. MCP Server Configuration for Filesystem Access**

```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "filesystem": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@modelcontextprotocol/server-filesystem"],
      "env": {
        "ALLOWED_DIRECTORIES": "C:,D:,E:,F:"
      }
    },

      "command": "npx",

```

#### **Migration Framework Specific Config (D:\Migration_Backup\.claude\settings.local.json)**


### **3. Enhanced Directory Structure**

# PopOS-PreFlight-Check.ps1 # Pop!_OS Migration Pre-Flight Validation Script # Version: 0.2.2 # Author: Migration Framework Team # Purpose: Comprehensive system check before Pop!_OS installation # # Usage: # Run as Administrator: powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File PopOS-PreFlight-Check.ps1 $ErrorActionPreference = "Continue" $report = @{ Timestamp = Get-Date System = @{} Blockers = @() Warnings = @() GreenLights = @() } Write-Host "=== Pop!_OS Pre-Flight Validation v2.2 ===" -ForegroundColor Cyan Write-Host "Generating compatibility report..." -ForegroundColor Yellow # 1. BitLocker Check (BLOCKER if enabled) Write-Host "`nChecking BitLocker status..." -NoNewline $bitlocker = Get-BitLockerVolume -MountPoint C: -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue if ($bitlocker.ProtectionStatus -eq "On") { $report.Blockers += "âŒ BitLocker is ACTIVE on C: drive - MUST disable before dual boot" Write-Host " BLOCKER!" -ForegroundColor Red } else { $report.GreenLights += "âœ… BitLocker is disabled" Write-Host " OK" -ForegroundColor Green } # 2. Fast Startup Check Write-Host "Checking Fast Startup..." -NoNewline $fastStartup = powercfg /a | Select-String "Fast startup" if ($fastStartup -match "available") { $report.Warnings += "âš ï¸ Fast Startup is enabled - must disable for dual boot" Write-Host " WARNING" -ForegroundColor Yellow } else { $report.GreenLights += "âœ… Fast Startup already disabled" Write-Host " OK" -ForegroundColor Green } # 3. System Integrity Write-Host "Checking Windows system integrity..." -NoNewline $sfcResult = sfc /verifyonly | Select-String "violations" if ($sfcResult) { $report.Warnings += "âš ï¸ Windows system files need repair - run 'sfc /scannow'" Write-Host " ISSUES FOUND" -ForegroundColor Yellow } else { $report.GreenLights += "âœ… Windows system files intact" Write-Host " OK" -ForegroundColor Green } # 4. Disk Space Analysis Write-Host "Analyzing disk space..." -NoNewline $fDrive = Get-PSDrive F -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue if ($fDrive.Free -lt 400GB) { $report.Blockers += "âŒ Insufficient space on F: drive (need 400GB, have $([math]::Round($fDrive.Free/1GB))GB)" Write-Host " INSUFFICIENT" -ForegroundColor Red } else { $report.GreenLights += "âœ… F: drive has $([math]::Round($fDrive.Free/1GB))GB free" Write-Host " OK" -ForegroundColor Green } # 5. Filesystem Health Check (v2.2 Feature!) Write-Host "Checking F: drive filesystem health..." -NoNewline $driveHealth = Get-PhysicalDisk | Where-Object {$_.FriendlyName -match "NVMe"} $allHealthy = $true foreach ($disk in $driveHealth) { if ($disk.HealthStatus -ne "Healthy") { $allHealthy = $false $report.Blockers += "âŒ Drive health issue detected: $($disk.FriendlyName) - $($disk.HealthStatus)" } } if ($allHealthy) { $report.GreenLights += "âœ… All drives report healthy status" Write-Host " OK" -ForegroundColor Green # Recommend chkdsk Write-Host "`nRECOMMENDED: Run 'chkdsk F: /f' before installation" -ForegroundColor Yellow $report.Warnings += "âš ï¸ Run 'chkdsk F: /f' to ensure filesystem integrity before installation" } else { Write-Host " ISSUES DETECTED!" -ForegroundColor Red } # 6. Critical Drivers Backup Write-Host "Exporting critical drivers list..." $report.System.Drivers = Get-WmiObject Win32_PnPSignedDriver | Where-Object {$_.DeviceName -match "Network|Display|Storage"} | Select-Object DeviceName, DriverVersion, DriverDate # 7. USB & Thunderbolt Devices Check (v2.2 Feature!) Write-Host "Checking USB and Thunderbolt devices..." -NoNewline $usbDevices = Get-PnpDevice -Class USB -PresentOnly | Where-Object {$_.Status -eq 'OK'} | Select-Object FriendlyName, DeviceID, Manufacturer $thunderboltDevices = Get-PnpDevice | Where-Object {$_.FriendlyName -match "Thunderbolt"} | Select-Object FriendlyName, DeviceID, Status $report.System.USBDevices = $usbDevices $report.System.ThunderboltDevices = $thunderboltDevices if ($usbDevices.Count -gt 0 -or $thunderboltDevices.Count -gt 0) { $report.Warnings += "âš ï¸ External devices detected - verify Linux compatibility" Write-Host " CHECK NEEDED" -ForegroundColor Yellow } else { Write-Host " OK" -ForegroundColor Green } # 8. Security Certificates Export Write-Host "Checking for certificates to migrate..." $certs = Get-ChildItem -Path Cert:\CurrentUser\My | Where-Object {$_.HasPrivateKey} | Select-Object Subject, Thumbprint, NotAfter if ($certs.Count -gt 0) { $report.System.Certificates = $certs $report.Warnings += "âš ï¸ Found $($certs.Count) certificates with private keys - manual export needed" } # 9. Password Manager Detection Write-Host "Checking for password managers..." $passwordManagers = @( @{Name="Bitwarden"; Path="$env:LOCALAPPDATA\Bitwarden"}, @{Name="1Password"; Path="$env:LOCALAPPDATA\1Password"}, @{Name="LastPass"; Path="$env:LOCALAPPDATA\LastPass"}, @{Name="KeePass"; Path="$env:PROGRAMFILES\KeePass*"} ) $foundManagers = @() foreach ($pm in $passwordManagers) { if (Test-Path $pm.Path) { $foundManagers += $pm.Name } } if ($foundManagers.Count -gt 0) { $report.System.PasswordManagers = $foundManagers $report.Warnings += "âš ï¸ Password manager(s) found: $($foundManagers -join ', ') - export vault before migration" } # 10. Network Configuration Export Write-Host "Exporting network configuration..." $report.System.NetworkConfig = @{ WiFiProfiles = netsh wlan show profiles | Select-String ":" | ForEach-Object {($_ -split ":")[1].Trim()} IPConfig = Get-NetIPConfiguration DNSServers = Get-DnsClientServerAddress } # 11. Installed Software Documentation Write-Host "Documenting installed software..." $report.System.Software = Get-ItemProperty HKLM:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall\* | Select-Object DisplayName, DisplayVersion, InstallDate | Where-Object {$_.DisplayName} | Sort-Object DisplayName # 12. Generate HTML Report $html = @" Pop!_OS Pre-Flight Report

Pop!_OS Migration Pre-Flight Report

Generated: $($report.Timestamp)

ğŸš« Blockers (Must Fix)

$(($report.Blockers | ForEach-Object {"

$_

"}) -join "")

âš ï¸ Warnings (Should Fix)

$(($report.Warnings | ForEach-Object {"

$_

"}) -join "")

âœ… Green Lights

$(($report.GreenLights | ForEach-Object {"

$_

"}) -join "")

ğŸ“Š System Information

Full details saved to: PopOS-PreFlight-SystemInfo.json

"@ $reportPath = "$env:USERPROFILE\Desktop\PopOS-PreFlight-Report.html" $html | Out-File -FilePath $reportPath -Encoding UTF8 $report | ConvertTo-Json -Depth 4 | Out-File "$env:USERPROFILE\Desktop\PopOS-PreFlight-SystemInfo.json" # Final Decision Write-Host "`n=== FINAL DECISION ===" -ForegroundColor Cyan if ($report.Blockers.Count -gt 0) { Write-Host "âŒ BLOCKED: Fix all blockers before proceeding!" -ForegroundColor Red Write-Host "Blockers found: $($report.Blockers.Count)" -ForegroundColor Red } elseif ($report.Warnings.Count -gt 0) { Write-Host "âš ï¸ PROCEED WITH CAUTION: Address warnings first" -ForegroundColor Yellow Write-Host "Warnings found: $($report.Warnings.Count)" -ForegroundColor Yellow } else { Write-Host "âœ… ALL CLEAR: System ready for Pop!_OS migration!" -ForegroundColor Green } Write-Host "`nReport saved to: $reportPath" -ForegroundColor Cyan Start-Process $reportPath Write-Host "`nğŸ“‹ Manual Validation Checklist:" -ForegroundColor Cyan Write-Host "- [ ] Photos du BIOS prises" -ForegroundColor Yellow Write-Host "- [ ] Mots de passe documentÃ©s" -ForegroundColor Yellow Write-Host "- [ ] ClÃ©s de licence sauvegardÃ©es" -ForegroundColor Yellow Write-Host "- [ ] Projets Git tous push" -ForegroundColor Yellow Write-Host "- [ ] Cloud drives synchronisÃ©s" -ForegroundColor Yellow
